values.title: Max limits in atlas_publishers_hz_gpu.test are too strict

content.raw:
The ROS hztest uses the hz_error to calculate max and min limits when used. Seems like our jenkins slave is being faster than expected. I believe that there is no way of defining different offsets for max and min limits so we probably need to relax the general error offset. Current list of failing tests:

```
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_disparity/test_hz][FAILURE]------
11: average rate (14.791Hz) exceeded maximum (12.500Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_left_camera_info/test_hz][FAILURE]
11: average rate (28.938Hz) exceeded maximum (20.000Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_left_image_raw/test_hz][FAILURE]-
11: average rate (29.009Hz) exceeded maximum (15.000Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_points/test_hz][FAILURE]---------
11: average rate (15.120Hz) exceeded maximum (12.500Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_points2/test_hz][FAILURE]--------
11: average rate (15.011Hz) exceeded maximum (12.500Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_right_camera_info/test_hz][FAILURE]
11: average rate (29.009Hz) exceeded maximum (20.000Hz)
11:
11: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_right_image_raw/test_hz][FAILURE]
11: average rate (28.935Hz) exceeded maximum (15.000Hz)
```
content.html:
The ROS hztest uses the hz_error to calculate max and min limits when used. Seems like our jenkins slave is being faster than expected. I believe that there is no way of defining different offsets for max and min limits so we probably need to relax the general error offset. Current list of failing tests:

values.title: Combine all IMU's and joints in the AtlasState message

content.raw:
The atlasState message doesn't contain

- hand joint angles, velocities
- laser spindle joint angle, velocity
- head/hand IMUs

This requires us to match the packets together to do full body state estimation and overly complicates the communication layer. It would be very useful if all these values where grouped in one message.

Same goes for the AtlasCommand message for the hands.

- Jesper
content.html:
The atlasState message doesn't contain

  • hand joint angles, velocities
  • laser spindle joint angle, velocity
  • head/hand IMUs

This requires us to match the packets together to do full body state estimation and overly complicates the communication layer. It would be very useful if all these values where grouped in one message.

Same goes for the AtlasCommand message for the hands.

  • Jesper

values.title: ROS interface to BDI STEP problems

content.raw:
The ROS interface to the BDI STEP behavior has at least two (possibly related) problems.  The first issue is that it doesn't place the foot at the desired location.  The second issue is that it is not possible to recover after entering the BDI STEP behavior.  Neither a command to STAND or an AtlasCommand can recover.  The only way is to re-start the simulator.  A test case is attached.

Expected behavior - left foot is placed higher as if putting the foot on a 10cm step
Actual behavior - right foot moves, BDI stuck in STEP mode, BDI STAND command and an AtlasCommand don't reset BDI module.  Message in window where Gazebo was started:
- user desired plan: 
Step 0
  duration 0.000000
  lfoot
    position 0.035572, 0.153140, 0.000008
    yaw 0.266051
    moved 0
    in_contact 1
  rfoot
    position 0.016008, -0.157999, 0.000048
    yaw -0.343160
    moved 0
    in_contact 1
(keeps repeating)

Issue is present in both drcsim 2.4 and 2.5.  Test case is for 2.5
Related discussion at:
http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/2424/drcsim-ros-interface-to-bdi-walk-and-step/
content.html:
The ROS interface to the BDI STEP behavior has at least two (possibly related) problems. The first issue is that it doesn't place the foot at the desired location. The second issue is that it is not possible to recover after entering the BDI STEP behavior. Neither a command to STAND or an AtlasCommand can recover. The only way is to re-start the simulator. A test case is attached.

Expected behavior - left foot is placed higher as if putting the foot on a 10cm step Actual behavior - right foot moves, BDI stuck in STEP mode, BDI STAND command and an AtlasCommand don't reset BDI module. Message in window where Gazebo was started: - user desired plan: Step 0 duration 0.000000 lfoot position 0.035572, 0.153140, 0.000008 yaw 0.266051 moved 0 in_contact 1 rfoot position 0.016008, -0.157999, 0.000048 yaw -0.343160 moved 0 in_contact 1 (keeps repeating)

Issue is present in both drcsim 2.4 and 2.5. Test case is for 2.5 Related discussion at: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/2424/drcsim-ros-interface-to-bdi-walk-and-step/

values.title: z value ignored for BDI walk

content.raw:
The z value appears to be ignored for the foot placement to the 4 step (WALK) interface to the BDI library. In particular, different z values for foot placement make no difference during the actual walking.  A test case is attached.  Issue is in both drcsim 2.4 and 2.5

Expected behavior - foot placement would be impacted by z value
Actual behavior - z value for foot placement appears to be ignored

values.title: atlas does not walk with 5steps.py

content.raw:
Atlas does not walk in gazebo with following commands.

        roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch
        rosrun atlas_utils 5steps.py

When I modify drcsim / ros / atlas_utils / scripts / 5steps.py as follows, atlas walks.

        - control_mode.publish("walk")
        + control_mode.publish("Walk") # first letter is upper‐case

values.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
In VRC Task 1, the rostopics responsible for publishing images from the MultisenseSL cameras are publishing at a frequency of roughly 15 Hz on average. This is only the case in Task 1; the same topics publish at rates of about 25-30 Hz in Tasks 2 and 3.

These rates are measured in simulation time. VRC Task 1 runs at a real-time factor of about 0.5, so I am only receiving roughly 8 images per second on average. I have attached some data, which is by no means exhaustive, but characterizes the problem I am seeing. The data presented are the rates reported by "rostopic hz" after running for 2 minutes simulation time.
content.html:
In VRC Task 1, the rostopics responsible for publishing images from the MultisenseSL cameras are publishing at a frequency of roughly 15 Hz on average. This is only the case in Task 1; the same topics publish at rates of about 25-30 Hz in Tasks 2 and 3.

These rates are measured in simulation time. VRC Task 1 runs at a real-time factor of about 0.5, so I am only receiving roughly 8 images per second on average. values.title: Updating Atlas Visuals

content.raw:
The new visuals looks great, but we have to address mismatches with existing collision shapes.

Pros:

  1.  New visuals better represents the actual hardware.
  1.  New visuals look (much) better.

Cons:

  1.  Using new visuals without changing the corresponding collision geometries can result in large visual interpenetration between Atlas robot and surrounding objects.  (The mismatches between new visuals and old collisions can be seen in the attached files).  This might also throw off 3D sensors when the robot tries to see itself.
  1.  If changes were made to the collision geometries to match the new visuals, given the short time frame to actual VRC, we might disrupt existing workflow or interfere with existing solution techniques that teams have been developing.

We should do one or some of below:

 1. Use the new visuals with old collisions and tolerate visual mesh interpenetrations.
 1. Update collision geometries to better match visuals, i.e.:
    a. change `lleg` collision geometries (see attached).
    a. add head shroud (protective cage) collision geometries.
    a. use a cage-less version of the `utorso` mesh (see attached).
    a. change `pelvis` collision geometries to match new visual with the new "tripod" pelvis.
    a. change all the arm collision geometries to match those of the new visuals.
content.html:
The new visuals looks great, but we have to address mismatches with existing collision shapes.

Pros:

  1. New visuals better represents the actual hardware.
  2. New visuals look (much) better.

Cons:

  1. Using new visuals without changing the corresponding collision geometries can result in large visual interpenetration between Atlas robot and surrounding objects. (The mismatches between new visuals and old collisions can be seen in the attached files). This might also throw off 3D sensors when the robot tries to see itself.
  2. If changes were made to the collision geometries to match the new visuals, given the short time frame to actual VRC, we might disrupt existing workflow or interfere with existing solution techniques that teams have been developing.

We should do one or some of below:

  1. Use the new visuals with old collisions and tolerate visual mesh interpenetrations.
  2. Update collision geometries to better match visuals, i.e.: a. change lleg collision geometries (see attached). a. add head shroud (protective cage) collision geometries. a. use a cage-less version of the utorso mesh (see attached). a. change pelvis collision geometries to match new visual with the new "tripod" pelvis. a. change all the arm collision geometries to match those of the new visuals.

values.title: BDI manipulate to stand transition fails

content.raw:
Transitioning from BDI STAND to MANIPULATE succeeds (drcsim-nightly 2.5.2 25-April), but going from a stable manipulate (slight squating) to STAND fails repeatedly.

Looking at plots of joint angles, there is a large disturbance that cause the robot to become unstable.

My understanding of STAND_PREP was from the earlier to modes that used a "harness" to initialize controllers.

Trying to call STAND_PREP after manipulate starts to stand, but then falls over immediately.

I'm not sure if this is a bug in software, or in my understanding of documentation.
content.html:
Transitioning from BDI STAND to MANIPULATE succeeds (drcsim-nightly 2.5.2 25-April), but going from a stable manipulate (slight squating) to STAND fails repeatedly.

Looking at plots of joint angles, there is a large disturbance that cause the robot to become unstable.

My understanding of STAND_PREP was from the earlier to modes that used a "harness" to initialize controllers.

Trying to call STAND_PREP after manipulate starts to stand, but then falls over immediately.

I'm not sure if this is a bug in software, or in my understanding of documentation.

values.title: Qual 2 needs gravity to be a reasonable qualifier

content.raw: There is a pinned_with_gravity mode that should be used for the qual 2 task rather than just pinned, which has no gravity.  Anyone who has done anything along the lines of manipulation needed for the VRC should have tuned control that works well in gravity situations.  By not having gravity, it makes the task much too simple.
content.html: There is a pinned_with_gravity mode that should be used for the qual 2 task rather than just pinned, which has no gravity. Anyone who has done anything along the lines of manipulation needed for the VRC should have tuned control that works well in gravity situations. By not having gravity, it makes the task much too simple.

values.title: atlas motion under bdi control does not perform the same under different real time factor

content.raw:
I ran the following scripted motion, (see below,using a modified Keyboard Teleop)
Atlas completes this without falling when using : atlas_utils atlas.launch
Atlas always loses balance when using : atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch

The only difference I could find in the parameters of the model was that the surface friction on the platforms was different that than the friction of the ground plane.  However, I also ran atlas on the ground plane of qual_task_1, with the same problem.

The other difference is that the atlas.launch simulation is running at: .32 real time factor, and the qual_task_1 is running at .18 (which is why I was running tests on the simpler world).  I would not think that running at a slower real time factor should effect the physics.

~~~
(x, y, theta, step number)
Walking Step Data 7 steps
foot: 0 [0.0, 0.1, 0.0, 0]
foot: 0 [0.25, 0.25, 0.0, 1]
foot: 1 [0.3658455931, 0.1688840425, 0.1745329252, 2]
foot: 0 [0.5152637125, 0.4893122335, 0.3490658504, 3]
foot: 1 [0.6434349889, 0.4295449858, 0.3490658504, 4]
foot: 0 [0.8462248827, 0.7191589685, 0.1745329252, 5]
foot: 1 [0.9462248827, 0.5191589685, 0.0, 6]
foot: 0 [0.9962248827, 0.6191589685, 0.0, 7]
now publish Stand
~~~

The other difference is that the atlas.launch simulation is running at: .32 real time factor, and the qual_task_1 is running at .18 (which is why I was running tests on the simpler world). I would not think that running at a slower real time factor should effect the physics.

values.title: Using /tmp in qual launch files breaks qual_task_# in multi-user systems

content.raw: In a similar vain to: [Gazebo Issue 631](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/631/using-tmp-gz_modeltargz-is-not-friendly) Having /tmp/qual_task_# hard-coded in the launch files will cause gazebo to crash for the Second user who has ran that qual world launch file, since they do not have permissions to overwrite the first user's directory.
content.html: In a similar vain to: Gazebo Issue 631 Having /tmp/qual_task_# hard-coded in the launch files will cause gazebo to crash for the Second user who has ran that qual world launch file, since they do not have permissions to overwrite the first user's directory.

values.title: Walking stops mid-trajectory with Atlas Sim Interface 1.1.0

content.raw:
When making several walking trajectories, eventually Atlas will stop mid trajectory. Usually it only takes 2 or 3 trajectories to get to this point. Re-issuing a basic walk command causes Atlas to respond much more erratically.

This is an issue currently seen with AtlasSimInterface_1.0.9_integration branch.

http://youtu.be/E-yAO3M3VdA

The consequence is that the enum types cannot be accessed pragmatically, and must be retrieved from the documents.

values.title: Crash in AtlasSimInterface from sending walk messages too quickly.

content.raw:
Not sure if there is a separate bug reporting mechanism for libAtlasSimInterface.so, but I'm adding it here for lack of a better option.

Crash is apparently because I errantly sent 4 walk messages in quick succession. 

Upon sending a walk command to /atlas/atlas_sim_interface_command Gazebo exits with no error message. Crash is repeatable.

values.title: DRC Vehicle can't make sharp turns

content.raw:
The DRC vehicle can't make sharp turns.  Note that this is a separate issue from [#176](#!/osrf/drcsim/issue/176/drc-vehicle-responds-very-slowly-in-drcsim) in which changes since drcsim 2.3 caused the vehicle to be unresponsive.  Even before the changes which made the vehicle unresponsive, it couldn't make sharp turns and had an unrealistically shallow turn radius.  

When driving at full speed this is not an issue since you don't need to do sharp turns and if you could it's likely that the vehicle would flip. However, if you are close to an obstacle and need to do a controlled two points turn it becomes a serious issue.  Instead of doing short controlled turns you end up moving virtually straight forwards and backwards, making little progress. When that happens, the odds of you going off course or hitting the obstacle that you're trying to avoid increase significantly.

My suggestion would be to increase the amount of torque it applies while turning.  This could cause the vehicle to flip over at speed, but is also easily avoided by just not applying the maximum steering angle. Which is how vehicles behave in the real-world.
content.html:
The DRC vehicle can't make sharp turns. Note that this is a separate issue from #176 in which changes since drcsim 2.3 caused the vehicle to be unresponsive. Even before the changes which made the vehicle unresponsive, it couldn't make sharp turns and had an unrealistically shallow turn radius.

When driving at full speed this is not an issue since you don't need to do sharp turns and if you could it's likely that the vehicle would flip. However, if you are close to an obstacle and need to do a controlled two points turn it becomes a serious issue. Instead of doing short controlled turns you end up moving virtually straight forwards and backwards, making little progress. When that happens, the odds of you going off course or hitting the obstacle that you're trying to avoid increase significantly.

My suggestion would be to increase the amount of torque it applies while turning. This could cause the vehicle to flip over at speed, but is also easily avoided by just not applying the maximum steering angle. Which is how vehicles behave in the real-world.

values.title: Implement user-controllable velocity filtering

content.raw:
OSRF should replace the raw velocity used in the PD controller and shipped to the user in atlas_states with a filtered velocity. The user should be able to set the filtering, and by setting the filtering coefficients appropriately, have no filtering at all. The filtering can be the same for all joints, or user settable for each joint.

The justification for this is in this discussion
#!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/248/per-issue-194-alternative-solution-add-ros/diff

and on this web page
http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/bdi2/

I have already shipped the relevant code to drcsim@osrffoundation.org
content.html:
OSRF should replace the raw velocity used in the PD controller and shipped to the user in atlas_states with a filtered velocity. The user should be able to set the filtering, and by setting the filtering coefficients appropriately, have no filtering at all. The filtering can be the same for all joints, or user settable for each joint.

The justification for this is in this discussion #!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/248/per-issue-194-alternative-solution-add-ros/diff

and on this web page http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/bdi2/

values.title: Use CFM damping to implement D term of PID control

content.raw:
How do we make the PD control on the simulator useful, given the large velocity noise?

Method 1: Implement the D gain as CFM damping, controllable on each tick. I really like this solution. People who want low damping can have it. People who want high damping can have it. CFM damping seems to be a much better implementation of damping that using SetForce(), in terms of actually being an energy sink.

See
#!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/248/per-issue-194-alternative-solution-add-ros/diff

and
http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/bdi2/
content.html:
How do we make the PD control on the simulator useful, given the large velocity noise?

Method 1: Implement the D gain as CFM damping, controllable on each tick. I really like this solution. People who want low damping can have it. People who want high damping can have it. CFM damping seems to be a much better implementation of damping that using SetForce(), in terms of actually being an energy sink.

See #!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/248/per-issue-194-alternative-solution-add-ros/diff

values.title: DRCSIM: Hand torque sensor - no X output

content.raw:
[Posted by Alberto Romay](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/2651/drcsim-hand-torque-sensor-no-x-output/)

The X component from the torque sensor of the hand is buggy. Z and Y components of the torque sensor in the wrist are giving an output while X is not. Discovered that only when the joint limits from the r_arm_mwx joint are reach the X starts giving an output.

[Hand torque sensor 1](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qwFaM3c1TJM) shows how the Z component is performing well, while the X is giving an output only when it reaches the joint limit (2:40).

[Hand torque sensor 2](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMcgStZbhTs) shows how the X component gives output only in the joint limits (upper 0:31 and lower 3:20).

values.title: GPU Lidar timestamp does not correspond with robot state

content.raw:
After the recent change to the GPU lidar, the timestamp of the lidar scan does not correspond with the state of the robot anymore. 

Using the ROS layer, we estimate the state of the robot and build a grid based on that showing the world. We created a simple test world (GazeboWorld.png) to show the issue.

With the old LIDAR scan, we are able to reconstruct a flat ground (see RaylidarGUIFlatGround.png), however with the new GPU Lidar the ground plane is tilted (GPURayLidarGUIFlatGround.png). Maximum tilt due spindle rotation is probably around 1/(40 Hz) * 5 rad/s = 0.125 rad, leading to an offset of 625mm at 5m distance.


We have seen the same issue when we simulate the LIDAR in our simulation software, and the solution was to determine the timestamp and the LIDAR transform to world (used to determine the origin of the scan) at the same time (blocking the simulation when doing this). Actually, in our simulation software we calculate the lidar transform and timestamp in the simulation thread and then notify the render thread to make the scan (while this could lead to a slightly outdated world, at least the timestamp is correct).

Note: Since the last updates I'm running at a realtime factor of 0.10 ~ 0.20 when the controller, sim and UI are running on my computer. Running at a realtime factor near 1.0 could mask this issue, but does not solve the issue and could lead to problems when the simulation rate drops during a run.
content.html:
After the recent change to the GPU lidar, the timestamp of the lidar scan does not correspond with the state of the robot anymore.

Using the ROS layer, we estimate the state of the robot and build a grid based on that showing the world. We created a simple test world (GazeboWorld.png) to show the issue.

With the old LIDAR scan, we are able to reconstruct a flat ground (see RaylidarGUIFlatGround.png), however with the new GPU Lidar the ground plane is tilted (GPURayLidarGUIFlatGround.png). Maximum tilt due spindle rotation is probably around 1/(40 Hz) * 5 rad/s = 0.125 rad, leading to an offset of 625mm at 5m distance.

We have seen the same issue when we simulate the LIDAR in our simulation software, and the solution was to determine the timestamp and the LIDAR transform to world (used to determine the origin of the scan) at the same time (blocking the simulation when doing this). Actually, in our simulation software we calculate the lidar transform and timestamp in the simulation thread and then notify the render thread to make the scan (while this could lead to a slightly outdated world, at least the timestamp is correct).

Note: Since the last updates I'm running at a realtime factor of 0.10 ~ 0.20 when the controller, sim and UI are running on my computer. Running at a realtime factor near 1.0 could mask this issue, but does not solve the issue and could lead to problems when the simulation rate drops during a run.

values.title: Listen for control messages using reliable() transport option (TCP), remove unreliable()

content.raw: With the synchronization plugin, lost messages will block the simulation and can result in loss of synchronization between the field computer and the simulation. It would be preferable if in order arrival of control messages is guaranteed by the simulation. As only subscribers can set the transport options, this needs to be done on the simulation side.
content.html: With the synchronization plugin, lost messages will block the simulation and can result in loss of synchronization between the field computer and the simulation. It would be preferable if in order arrival of control messages is guaranteed by the simulation. As only subscribers can set the transport options, this needs to be done on the simulation side.

values.title: Vehicle still drifting in drcsim-nightly

content.raw:
The vehicle is still slowly moving back and forth while it's supposed to be stopped. 

near_start.png shows the vehicle shortly after it starts drifting forward. 
shifted_forward.png shows the vehicle right before it stars to move backward. 
back_at_start.png shows the vehicle when it has drifted back close to the starting point.
rotated_car.png shows the vehicle rotated after a few iterations of drifting forward and back.

The cloud being displayed in rviz consists of the last 500 laser scan readings. All of these were taken after launching vrc_task_1.launch in atlas_utils. Our only modification was to change the starting position of atlas to be next to the car. We did not send any commands to any topic.

We're using the nightly build of drcsim / gazebo, so I think we should be running pull request #140 (supposed to fix this drifting problem).

values.title: AtlasSimInterfaceState message has no stamp information

content.raw: The [atlas_msgs/AtlasSimInterfaceState](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/3deeff82b93e/ros/atlas_msgs/msg/AtlasSimInterfaceState.msg?at=default) message contains no timestamp information, although some of the contained data (pelvis position, feet poses) only becomes usable when it is also stamped (at least from a picky POV ;) ). Of course, one can always guess a stamp (e.g. "now"). Any reasons why there isn't any?

values.title: Publish scoring module state

content.raw:
Would it be possible to publish one more topic containing the state of the scoring module, say at 1Hz?  In particular it would be helpful to have access to the following information at all times:

- current task
- time remaining
- checkpoints remaining
- lives remaining (3 - how many times the robot has been damaged in this run)
- uplink bits remaining
- downlink bits remaining

In principle we can keep track of all this ourselves, but if our software crashes and needs to be restarted during a run, this crucial information will be lost.  Furthermore, some of these states we cannot really compute -- for example the acceleration used to determine if the robot is damaged (we only have noisy velocity data).  Currently Gazebo prints a message on the console if the robot is damaged, but we will not be looking at the Field Computer console during the VRC.  Similarly, after all the debates on bit counting, it would be nice to know the state of the official bit counter at all times (and reduce our data transmission if we are about to run out of bits).
content.html:
Would it be possible to publish one more topic containing the state of the scoring module, say at 1Hz? In particular it would be helpful to have access to the following information at all times:

  • current task
  • time remaining
  • checkpoints remaining
  • lives remaining (3 - how many times the robot has been damaged in this run)
  • uplink bits remaining
  • downlink bits remaining

In principle we can keep track of all this ourselves, but if our software crashes and needs to be restarted during a run, this crucial information will be lost. Furthermore, some of these states we cannot really compute -- for example the acceleration used to determine if the robot is damaged (we only have noisy velocity data). Currently Gazebo prints a message on the console if the robot is damaged, but we will not be looking at the Field Computer console during the VRC. Similarly, after all the debates on bit counting, it would be nice to know the state of the official bit counter at all times (and reduce our data transmission if we are about to run out of bits).

values.title: Buildings in task 1 are saturated black and hill textures took a step backwards

content.raw:
The two attached image show the same scene in different recent versions of drcsim.  In the older image, the white building is almost at saturation, while in the new version the darker buildings are almost at saturation.  Both cases are undeserable since they reduce the number of features which can be tracked for SFM.  Having buildings which are saturated black is less desirable than having buildings which are saturated white since color based segmentation will mistake it for roads.

The older hill texture is also preferable to the new texture since it is more unique.  The new texture appears to be a small pattern cloned many time creating many repeat patterns.

The new image is from default drcsim.

The new image is from default drcsim.

values.title: Setting sensor rates

content.raw:
* /multisense_sl/fps   ... sets the rate of the camera image
* /multisense_sl/set_spindle_speed ... sets the rate of the spinde speed

I suggest the former be changed to "set_fps" for consistency.

Also the sandia hand cameras don't have channels to set their rates:

* /sandia_hands/l_hand/set_fps

* /sandia_hands/r_hand/set_fps

They are also not rate limited - they generate images different rates (e.g. I've seen 50Hz).

values.title: /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh takes a long time

content.raw:
The setup.sh script uses find to find the correct drcsim directory, but this takes a long time (especially when it doesn't have an SSD, like our gazebo computers). 

Especially when adding setup.sh to your ~/.bashrc starting a new terminal or logging in to a computer takes many seconds.
content.html:
The setup.sh script uses find to find the correct drcsim directory, but this takes a long time (especially when it doesn't have an SSD, like our gazebo computers).

Especially when adding setup.sh to your ~/.bashrc starting a new terminal or logging in to a computer takes many seconds.

values.title: Scale incorrect in atlas.urdf files

content.raw:
In atlas.urdf, the scale for several links is set to 100.0. Looking at the corresponding .dae file the resolution of the joint is set to centimeters

    <unit meter="1.0" name="centimeter"></unit>

This screws up our model loader, as it uses the correct units and now the links are extremely big. Especially considering .sdf/.urdf are interchange formats, it is poor form to compensate for errors in the model file (I can disable scaling in our loader but everything that actually uses scale will be screwed up).

values.title: Erratic vehicle behavior when breaks are applied and when accelerating

content.raw:
The vehicle tends to skid and spin when bringing it to a stop when using the break pedal.  Skidding and spinning also happens when applying the gas, but is much more of a problem while breaking.  Gently applying the gas and breaks reduces the problem but doesn't get rid of it.  *Based on the tests that I've performed you could easily apply the breaks in a controlled manor at a resonable distance and crash into obstacles while spinning or skid out of the course at the end.*

Relaxation of the rules in task 1 no longer make this a fatal flaw, but it does add a significant random element beyound the quality of your control algorithms.  

Definition of "gently":  When acceleraterating the gas pedal's value is linearly increased over the course of 2 seconds.  When decelerating the break pedal's value is linearly increased over the course of 2 seconds.  

Image:  The attached image shows the car executing the exact same sequence of commands 10 times.  The steering wheel is at a constant 107 degrees.  Blue lines indicate the orientation of the vehicle.  There should be a constant angle relative to the trajectory.  If they are not, then the vehicle is rotating while skidding.  These tests were performed on road terrain.  Note the outlier in the upper right, that was caused by skidding during acceleration.

The vehicle tends to skid and spin when bringing it to a stop when using the break pedal. Skidding and spinning also happens when applying the gas, but is much more of a problem while breaking. Gently applying the gas and breaks reduces the problem but doesn't get rid of it. Based on the tests that I've performed you could easily apply the breaks in a controlled manor at a resonable distance and crash into obstacles while spinning or skid out of the course at the end.

Relaxation of the rules in task 1 no longer make this a fatal flaw, but it does add a significant random element beyound the quality of your control algorithms.

values.title: Don't count falls after completing the task
Check that Atlas is not in the car when crossing the last gate in V1
firehose issues

content.raw:
A couple of issues with the firehose as of trunk today:

1) I think the physical behaviour is a big issue. It moves/vibrates/slides at a significant rate. The handle seems to typically turn up gradually over time. The second joint on the hose vibrates to the left side of the table and then falls off.
Thus its possible that the hose could have passively fallen off the table before a team can walk there.
This makes the problem difficult unintentionally variable and its not clear that its physically realistic.
I could think of a number of fixes for this - but can you ensure that the hose will be on the table?

2) The texture on the blue handle is very very weak. Stereo Block Matching gives almost no returns. All the other objects (valve, hose, drill, standpipe and car parts) were fine in this regard. Could you increase the texture on it?

This allow teams to confidently plan their bandwidth usage.

This was also requested by @DavidC on the DRC forum.

* Dbg connectPose 1.2e-05 -0.125623 0.35 -0.041215 -1.57078 1.61199
* Dbg relativePose 0.299871 0.139127 -1.19833 0.000399 -1.50144 1.56706
* Dbg connect offset -1.54832 -0.299852 -0.264782 -0.003327 0.069336 -0.000259
* Dbg xyz 1.59917
* Dbg rpy 0.0694017
* Dbg valve -1.21592e-12
* Dbg relPose.Zaxis -0.003331 -0.99759 0.069297
* Dbg connPose.Zaxis -2.2e-05 -1 1.6e-05
* Dbg coupling.Zaxis -0.003331 0.069201 0.997597
* Dbg spout.Zaxis 0 1 9.6e-05
* Dbg rotErr_cga 1.36433

At the start the hose points away from the spigot, so having a small rotErr
is bad (0.0694017). The rotErr should be maximal.

The main issue is that the "Z axis" of the hose points upward along the Z axis.
It should point horizontally along the long axis of the coupling, as the hose is horizontal at the start of the task. I see that coupling_relative_pose in the world file
compensates for this. I don't think it is correct. It means the robot needs to very carefully never rotate the coupling about its long axis during the connection. This conflicts with screwing the coupling by rotating it around its long axis.
It also means that any orientation of the coupling with that "Z axis" aligned with
the z axis is okay (including pointing away from the spout, or being perpendicular to it.

I believe this is what is preventing attachment when it appears the hose is correctly aligned.

I think the hose coupling should be redefined so it's Z axis is along its long axis.

Here are some printouts with the coupling in what we believe is roughly the right place and alignment.
Note that coupling.Zaxis is very different in the two runs.

* coupling -3.18106 -4.10214 1.36715 0.621199 0.009171 -1.56043
* spout -3.18 -4.09 1.37 -1.5707 0 -0
* connectPose 1.2e-05 0 0 2.97 1.48 -0.275
* relativePose -0.001061 0.002849 -0.01214 2.91118 1.55702 0.719231
* connect offset 0.011926 -0.00291 0.002439 -1.0515 -0.080077 -0.025667
* xyz 0.0125155
* rpy 1.00531
* valve -1.2168e-12
* relPose.Zaxis -0.581902 -0.813148 -0.013411
* connPose.Zaxis -0.990752 0.102121 -0.08934
* coupling.Zaxis -0.581902 -0.013489 0.813147
* spout.Zaxis 0 1 9.6e-05
* rotErr_cga 1.42366

and

* coupling -3.1951 -4.10624 1.37255 1.74921 0.016014 -1.37723
* spout -3.18 -4.09 1.37 -1.5707 -0 -0
* connectPose 1.2e-05 0 0 2.97 1.48 1.075
* relativePose -0.015105 -0.002557 -0.016241 -2.88217 1.37658 0.082577
* connect offset 0.015318 -0.01376 0.008652 1.41509 -0.01173 0.162707
* xyz 0.0223347
* rpy 1.29995
* valve -1.2168e-12
* relPose.Zaxis -0.966294 0.177429 -0.186535
* connPose.Zaxis -0.316623 -0.944335 -0.08934
* coupling.Zaxis -0.966294 -0.186518 -0.177447
* spout.Zaxis 0 1 9.6e-05
* rotErr_cga 1.54048

Here is the relevant code. I thought rotErr_cga would be the right answer, but it is not given the definition of the axes. Probably the X or Y axis for the coupling link would have worked.


```
#!c++
  double rotErr_cga
    = (this->drcFireHose.couplingLink->GetWorldPose().rot.GetZAxis() -
       this->drcFireHose.spoutLink->GetWorldPose().rot.GetZAxis()).GetLength();

      gzdbg << "\ncoupling " << this->drcFireHose.couplingLink->GetWorldPose() \
<< "\n";
      gzdbg << "spout " << this->drcFireHose.spoutLink->GetWorldPose() << "\n";
      gzdbg << "connectPose " << connectPose << "\n";
      gzdbg << "relativePose " << relativePose << "\n";
      gzdbg << "connect offset " << connectOffset << "\n";
      gzdbg << "xyz " << posErr << "\n";
      gzdbg << "rpy " << rotErr << "\n";
      gzdbg << "valve " << valveAng << "\n";
      gzdbg << "relPose.Zaxis " << relativePose.rot.GetZAxis() << "\n";
      gzdbg << "connPose.Zaxis " << connectPose.rot.GetZAxis() << "\n";
      gzdbg << "coupling.Zaxis " << this->drcFireHose.couplingLink->GetWorldPos\
e().rot.GetZAxis() << "\n";
      gzdbg << "spout.Zaxis " << this->drcFireHose.spoutLink->GetWorldPose().ro\
t.GetZAxis() << "\n";
      gzdbg << "rotErr_cga " << rotErr_cga << "\n";


```

values.title: DRCSIM recently stopped working with Intel graphics cards

content.raw: Since a recent update (not sure which one exactly), drcsim-nightly doesn't work with the Intel graphics card on one of our laptops anymore and segfaults (Ubuntu 12.04). Starting plain gazebo works. It will crash if a Atlas model is inserted however (while it only complains about missing ROS plugins on other computers, but will not crash). I suspect some of the recent changes related to GPU ray sensors might be responsible. The current version of drcsim (non-nightly) still works.
content.html: Since a recent update (not sure which one exactly), drcsim-nightly doesn't work with the Intel graphics card on one of our laptops anymore and segfaults (Ubuntu 12.04). Starting plain gazebo works. It will crash if a Atlas model is inserted however (while it only complains about missing ROS plugins on other computers, but will not crash). I suspect some of the recent changes related to GPU ray sensors might be responsible. The current version of drcsim (non-nightly) still works.

values.title: mud_box, mud_atlas models not automatically loaded in 2.6

content.raw:
There is no joy in mudville.

In the process of bringing up drcsim 2.6 using

sudo apt-get install drcsim

having deleted .gazebo/models

stuff from mud_box, mud_atlas are missing.

mud_atlas is in /usr/share/drcsim-2.6/gazebo_models/environments but is missing the materials subdirectory. I copied that from a drcsim-2.5 machine.
Why that is necessary is unclear to me since it no longer appears in the mud_atlas/model.sdf, but error messages indicated it was clearly needed.

Appears model://mud_atlas/materials/  is needed in 
worlds/vrc_task_2.world,
worlds/vrc_task_2_stumps.world

I got mud_box using

hg clone https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models gazebo_models

I manually copied mud_box to ~/.gazebo/models

values.title: GPU lidar noise misbehaviour

content.raw:
With the latest nightly builds, the GPU laser is generating unexpected returns when noise is added to free space returns (i.e. returns that don't intersect with anything.)

For example:
when a return of 30m is created (i.e. no return):

* A. some reported returns are 30m
* B. some reported returns are 29.9XXX 
* C. some reported returns are 0.1

I see this as the GPU ray tracer is returning 30m and then noise is added to result in the two odd cases (B & C).

@gerkey @nkoenig @thomasko have you seen this? Can you test this?

values.title: Firehose grasping is non physical on body movement

content.raw:
Grasping the firehose coupling is unstable on body movement. Any body movement against the axis of the grasp makes it non-physical. 

- See [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iBD9FAfLguI](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iBD9FAfLguI).

**Setup**

1. grasp commands via sandia_hand_msgs/SimpleGrasp.
1. and keyboard teleop to move a pinned robot.



- Tested torque based power grasps upto max torque limits in the hand urdf  (28Nm- which is very high), the problem persists.
- The problem persists for position based grasps also.
- Tested on a simple geometry such as a cylinder to replace the hexagonal mesh and the problem persists ([http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhE6_uxgLpA](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhE6_uxgLpA)).
- Experimented with the min_depth and mu,mu2 parameters for both the hands and the firehose sdf and the problem persists.

We think this is a simulation issue that needs to be resolved to enable body movement while holding objects.
content.html:
Grasping the firehose coupling is unstable on body movement. Any body movement against the axis of the grasp makes it non-physical.

  • See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iBD9FAfLguI.

Setup

  1. grasp commands via sandia_hand_msgs/SimpleGrasp.
  2. and keyboard teleop to move a pinned robot.
  • Tested torque based power grasps upto max torque limits in the hand urdf (28Nm- which is very high), the problem persists.
  • The problem persists for position based grasps also.
  • Tested on a simple geometry such as a cylinder to replace the hexagonal mesh and the problem persists (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhE6_uxgLpA).
  • Experimented with the min_depth and mu,mu2 parameters for both the hands and the firehose sdf and the problem persists.

We think this is a simulation issue that needs to be resolved to enable body movement while holding objects.

values.title: Fix user guide to describe new usage of kp_velocity and provide description

content.raw:
Recent changes (2.6.1) provide a set_joint_damping service, and it appears that kp_velocity is used both in control damping and to set_joint_damping.

This is a recent and significant change, but the impacts are not discussed on the user guide, and the controls reference is out of date.

It appears that usage of kp_velocity (and/or joint_damping) is necessary to provide simulator stability. See issue #273.

As we are not all experts in rigid body dynamic simulation, please provide guidelines for usage, and a discussion of how this impacts the underlying physics simulation (beyond the once per time step controls calculation in plugin).

I'm posting a companion question on answers.gazebosim.org, but this information should be shared with community on the official users guide.
content.html:
Recent changes (2.6.1) provide a set_joint_damping service, and it appears that kp_velocity is used both in control damping and to set_joint_damping.

This is a recent and significant change, but the impacts are not discussed on the user guide, and the controls reference is out of date.

It appears that usage of kp_velocity (and/or joint_damping) is necessary to provide simulator stability. See issue #273.

As we are not all experts in rigid body dynamic simulation, please provide guidelines for usage, and a discussion of how this impacts the underlying physics simulation (beyond the once per time step controls calculation in plugin).

I'm posting a companion question on answers.gazebosim.org, but this information should be shared with community on the official users guide.

values.title: Atlas slides forward

content.raw: It appears that when standing still, Atlas continuously slides forward at a very slow rate. I observed this on all three task maps using the latest version of drcsim (2.6.1).

values.title: vibrating valve and standpipe

content.raw:
We see vibrating valves and standpipes in our current version:
[http://youtu.be/QXcuCWUvWEs](http://youtu.be/QXcuCWUvWEs)
The vibration is not always present - it seems to depend on initial conditions.

@gerkey @nkoenig Can the valve and standpipe be shorted to hang a few mm short of the wall?

We see vibrating valves and standpipes in our current version: http://youtu.be/QXcuCWUvWEs The vibration is not always present - it seems to depend on initial conditions.

values.title: atlas .stl files are outdated

content.raw:
The ``.stl`` files used by the atlas urdf without simplified collision model are those of the old atlas model.

    for i in ./*.dae; do meshlabserver -om vn fn -i $i -o ./`basename $i .dae`.stl; done

should do the trick to update them from within the meshes directory (meshlab needs to be installed).
content.html:

values.title: Mystery of the Sinking Utility Vehicle

content.raw:
In the latest version (2.6.2) the rear wheels of the utility vehicle sink into the Aluminum diamond plate after the robot is teleported to the vehicle.

Probably related - the robots legs can penetrate the floor of the vehicle.
